summary: Banff National Park is Canada's first national park, established in 1885 as Rocky Mountains Park. Located in Alberta's Rocky Mountains, Banff encompasses 6,641 square kilometres (2,564 sq mi) of mountainous terrain. Mammal species such as grizzly bear, cougar, wolverine, elk, bighorn sheep and moose are found, along with hundreds of bird species.

Jasper National Park, in Alberta, Canada, is the largest national park within Alberta's Rocky Mountains. It was established as Jasper Forest Park in 1907, renamed as a national park in 1930, and declared a UNESCO world heritage site in 1984. The park contains the glaciers of the Columbia Icefield, springs, lakes, waterfalls and mountains.

The word Yoho is a Cree expression of amazement or awe. Yoho covers an area of 1,313 square kilometres (507 sq mi) It is in the traditional territories of the Secwepemc and Ktunaxa First Nations. The contiguous national parks of Banff, Jasper, Kootenay, and Yoho, as well as Mount Robson, Mount Assiniboine, and Hamber provincial parks, were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1984.

Kootenay National Park is a national park of Canada in southeastern British Columbia. The park consists of 1,406 km2 (543 sq mi) of the Canadian Rockies. It was created in 1920 as part of an agreement between the province of British Columbia and the Canadian federal government to build a highway.

Waterton Lakes National Park is in the southwest corner of Alberta, Canada. It was the fourth Canadian national park, formed in 1895 as Kootenay Lakes Forest Reserve. It is named after Waterton Lake, in turn after the Victorian naturalist and conservationist Charles Waterton. This park contains 505 km2 (195 sq mi) of rugged mountains and wilderness.

Mount Revelstoke National Park is a national park in British Columbia, Canada. It is located in the Selkirk Mountains and was founded in 1914. The park contains a portion of one of the world's few inland temperate rainforests. It protects a small herd of the threatened caribou as well as providing habitats for cougars, grizzly bears, lynxes, black bears, red foxes, moose, martens, coyotes, a variety of bats, timber wolves, several species of shrews and voles.

Glacier National Park may refer to several places in the U.S. It may also refer to the site of the World War II Battle of the Alaskan Outback. The National Park Service operates Glacier National Park in Alaska. The park is home to some of the world's most spectacular scenery.

Riding Mountain National Park is a national park in Manitoba, Canada. It protects three different ecosystems that converge in the area; grasslands, upland boreal and eastern deciduous forests. The park is located within Treaty 2 Territory and sits atop the Manitoba Escarpment. First Nations peoples have lived in the region for several thousand years.

Glenbow Ranch Provincial Park is a provincial park in the Calgary Region of Alberta, Canada. The majority of the park is located on the north bank of the Bow River within Rocky View County. Portions of the eastern and western extremities are located within the City of Calgary and the Town of Cochrane respectively.

Bow Valley Provincial Park is a provincial park in Alberta, Canada. It is located at the eastern edge of Alberta's Rocky Mountains in the Bow Valley. It includes forested areas, meadows, lakes, and an area of unusual "warm" springs. There are also glacial landforms such as eskers, kames, moraines, and kettle lakes.

Yellowstone National Park is a national park of the United States located in the northwest corner of Wyoming and extending into Montana and Idaho. It was established by the 42nd U.S. Congress through the Yellowstone National Park Protection Act and signed into law by President Ulysses S. Grant on March 1, 1872. The park is known for its wildlife and its many geothermal features, especially the Old Faithful geyser, one of its most popular.

Yosemite National Park is a national park of the United States in California. It is bordered on the southeast by Sierra National Forest and on the northwest by Stanislaus National Forest. The park is managed by the National Park Service and covers 759,620 acres (1,187 sq mi; 3,074 km2) Almost 95 percent of the park is designated wilderness.

Grand Canyon National Park is a national park of the United States located in northwestern Arizona. The park's central feature is the Grand Canyon, a gorge of the Colorado River, which is often considered one of the Wonders of the World. The Grand Canyon was designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979. It celebrated its 100th anniversary on February 26, 2019.

Great Smoky Mountains National Park is a national park of the United States in the southeast, with parts in North Carolina and Tennessee. The park contains some of the highest mountains in eastern North America, including Kuwohi, Mount Guyot, and Mount Le Conte. The Appalachian Trail passes through the center of the park on its route from Georgia to Maine. With 13 million visitors in 2023, it is the most visited national park in the U.S.

Zion National Park is a national park of the United States located in southwestern Utah near the town of Springdale. The park has a unique geography and a variety of life zones that allow for unusual plant and animal diversity. Numerous plant species as well as 289 species of birds, 75 mammals (including 19 species of bat), and 32 reptiles inhabit the park's four life zones.

Glacier National Park may refer to several places in the U.S. It may also refer to the site of the World War II Battle of the Alaskan Outback. The National Park Service operates Glacier National Park in Alaska. The park is home to some of the world's most spectacular scenery.

Rocky Mountain National Park is a national park of the United States. It is located in north-central Colorado, within the Front Range of the Rocky Mountains. The park is one of the most visited in the National Park System, ranking as the third most visited national park in 2015. In 2019, the park saw record attendance yet again with 4,678,804 visitors, a 44% increase since 2012.

Acadia National Park is a national park of the United States located along the mid-section of the Maine coast, southwest of Bar Harbor. The park includes about half of Mount Desert Island, part of the Isle au Haut, the tip of the Schoodic Peninsula, and portions of sixteen smaller outlying islands. In total, it encompasses 49,075 acres (19,860 ha; 76.680 sq mi; 198.60 km2)

Despite its name, Bryce Canyon is not a canyon, but a collection of giant natural amphitheaters along the eastern side of the Paunsaugunt Plateau. Bryce is distinctive due to geological structures called hoodoos, formed by frost weathering and stream erosion of the river and lake bed sedimentary rock. The park covers 35,835 acres (55.992 sq mi; 14,502 ha; 145.02 km2) and receives substantially fewer visitors than Zion National Park.

Arches National Park is a national park of the United States in eastern Utah. It contains more than 2,000 natural sandstone arches, including the well-known Delicate Arch. The park lies above an underground evaporite layer or salt bed, which is the main cause of the formation of the arches. The highest elevation in the park is 5,653 ft (1,723 m) at Elephant Butte.

Kruger National Park is one of the largest game reserves in Africa. It covers an area of 19,623 km2 (7,576 sq mi) in the provinces of Limpopo and Mpumalanga in northeastern South Africa. Areas of the park were first protected by the government of the South African Republic in 1898. It became South Africa's first national park in 1926.

The Serengeti is a large area of land in southern Tanzania. It is home to more than 1,000 species of wild animals. The area was designated as a national park in 1961. The park was established to protect the wild animals from habitat loss. It was declared open to the public in 1973.

The daily transcript is a written version of each day's featured news story. Use this transcript to help people with reading comprehension and vocabulary. Use the weekly Newsquiz to test your knowledge of stories you saw on CNN.com. Today's Daily transcript includes a summary of the week's news stories.

Chobe National Park is Botswana's first national park, and also the most biologically diverse. The park is widely known for its large elephant population, estimated to be around 50,000. Elephants living here are Kalahari elephants, the largest in herd size of all known elephant populations. Road conditions depend greatly on the season and rainfall.

The daily transcript is a written version of each day's featured news story. Use this transcript to help people with reading comprehension and vocabulary. Use the weekly Newsquiz to test your knowledge of stories you saw on CNN.com. Today's Daily transcript includes a summary of the week's news stories.

The national park was founded in 1980 to protect the Komodo dragon, the world's largest lizard. Later it was dedicated to protecting other species, including marine species. In 1991 it was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a Man and Biosphere Reserve. It is also a WWF Global 200 Marine Eco-region, a WWF/IUCN Centre of Plant Diversity, and an ASEAN Heritage Park.

Fiordland National Park is a national park in the south-west corner of South Island of New Zealand. It is the largest of the 13 national parks in New Zealand, with an area covering 12,607 km2 (4,868 sq mi) It is a major part of the Te Wāhipounamu a UNESCO World Heritage Site established in 1990. The park is administered by the Department of Conservation.

Torres del Paine National Park is a national park in southern Chile. Paine means "blue" in the native Tehuelche (Aonikenk) language and is pronounced PIE-neh. It was established as a National Park in 1959. The park averages around 252,000 visitors a year.

Banff National Park is Canada's first national park, established in 1885 as Rocky Mountains Park. Located in Alberta's Rocky Mountains, Banff encompasses 6,641 square kilometres (2,564 sq mi) of mountainous terrain. Mammal species such as grizzly bear, cougar, wolverine, elk, bighorn sheep and moose are found, along with hundreds of bird species.

Iguaçu National Park is a national park in Paraná State, Brazil. It has one of the world's largest waterfalls, extending over some 2,700 meters (8,900 ft) The park is home to many rare and endangered species of flora and fauna. It became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1986.

Victoria Falls National Park protects the south and east bank of the Zambezi River in the area of the world-famous Victoria Falls. A notable feature of the park is the rainforest which grows in the spray of the falls. Visitors have the chance to view the elephant, Cape buffalo, southern white rhinoceros, hippopotamus, giraffes and other antelope herds.

Denali National Park and Preserve, formerly known as Mount McKinley National Park, is a U.S. national park and preserve located in Interior Alaska, centered on Denali, the highest mountain in North America. The park and contiguous preserve encompass 6,045,153 acres (2,446,387 ha; 9,446 sq mi; 24,464 km2) which is larger than the state of New Hampshire. The oldest site within park boundaries is the Teklanika River site, dated to about 7130 BC.

Sundarbans National Park is a national park in West Bengal, India, and core part of tiger reserve and biosphere reserve. The total area (including water) was estimated at 16,900 square kilometres (6,526 sq mi). It was a water-logged jungle, in which tigers and other wild beasts abounded.

Etosha National Park is one of the largest national parks in Africa. It spans an area of 22,270 km2 (8,600 sq mi) and was named after the large Etosha pan which is almost entirely within the park. The park is home to hundreds of species of mammals, birds and reptiles.

Saguaro National Park is a national park of the United States in southeastern Arizona. The park consists of two separate parcels, the Tucson Mountain District (TMD) to the west of Tucson, Arizona, and the Rincon Mountain District to the east. Both districts preserve Sonoran Desert landscapes, fauna, and flora, including the giant saguaro cactus. About 71,000 acres (29,000 ha) of the park, including large fractions of both districts, is designated wilderness.

Yellowstone National Park is a national park of the United States located in the northwest corner of Wyoming and extending into Montana and Idaho. It was established by the 42nd U.S. Congress through the Yellowstone National Park Protection Act and signed into law by President Ulysses S. Grant on March 1, 1872. The park is known for its wildlife and its many geothermal features, especially the Old Faithful geyser, one of its most popular.

Mount Kenya National Park is a national park in Kenya. It was established in 1949 to protect its surrounding environment and wildlife. It is also a drainage basin for the region's water supply. In April 1978, the area was designated a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. It became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1997.

Maasai Mara is a large national game reserve in Narok, Kenya, contiguous with the Serengeti National Park in Tanzania. It is one of the wildlife conservation and wilderness areas in Africa, with its populations of lions, leopards, cheetahs and African bush elephants. Maasai people make up a community that spans northern, central and southern Kenya and northern parts of Tanzania.

The Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve is a wildlife sanctuary in Chandrapur district of Maharashtra state in India. It is Maharashtra's oldest and largest national park. Created in 1955, the reserve includes the Tadoba National Park and the Andhari Wildlife Sanctuary. The reserve consists of 577.96 square kilometres (223.15 sq mi) of reserved forest and 32.51 sq kilometres (12.55 sq mi) of protected forest.
